title: Ervin powers San Jose State past New Mexico
text:
Ervin powers San Jose State past New Mexico By Ray Hacke Posted: 10/24/2015 07:04:32 PM PDT Updated: 10/24/2015 10:27:16 PM PDT SAN JOSE -- Tyler Ervin gave San Jose State's bowl hopes a big boost Saturday evening in leading the Spartans to a 31-21 win over New Mexico at Spartan Stadium. 
Ervin rushed for 263 yards on 36 carries, scored a touchdown and reached several milestones as the Spartans (4-4, 3-2 Mountain West Conference) garnered a much-needed victory after their Oct. 17 loss to San Diego State. SJSU now needs to win just two games to become bowl-eligible. 
It won't be easy -- San Jose State's November slate includes home dates against Brigham Young and Boise State and tough road games at Nevada and Hawaii. But beating New Mexico (4-4, 2-2) was a good first step. San Jose State's Tyler Ervin tries to fend off New Mexico's Nik D'Avanzo in the second quarter at San Jose State University in San Jose, Calif., on Saturday, Oct. 24, 2015. (Jim Gensheimer/Bay Area News Group) ( Jim Gensheimer ) 
"We know how much we have left to play for," junior quarterback Kenny Potter said. "We have to get to 6-6 or 7-5, whatever it may be. 
"The conference championship's not fully in our hands -- some things have to happen for us to win that. But as far as what we can control, it's a bowl right now, and that's our goal." 
Ervin moved into second place on San Jose State's career all-purpose yardage list, finishing the game with 5,225. He surpassed 5,000 on his second carry, a 71-yard touchdown run that helped the Spartans go up 7-0. 
The senior tailback also became the 11th Spartan to rush for 1,000 yards in a season, surpassing the mark on a 3-yard run in the second quarter, and the fourth with two 200-yard rushing games in a season. Ervin is seventh on SJSU's single-season rushing list with 1,159 yards. Advertisement 
"It all starts with No. 7," Potter said, referring to Ervin's jersey number. "He's pretty incredible -- you just hand him the ball and watch him go. It's fun to watch." 
Potter did some pretty incredible things himself, completing 16 of 20 passes for 181 yards and two TDs with no interceptions. He also came through with two huge scoring plays at crucial moments. 
The first of those came just before halftime. With the score tied at 14, Potter lofted a short pass over several Lobos defenders to wide-open tight end Billy Freeman for a 25-yard score that put SJSU ahead to stay. 
Potter then turned a potentially huge loss of yardage into a 12-yard insurance TD in the third quarter. With all of his receivers covered, Potter suddenly found himself under pressure from an oncoming pass rusher. After first rushing backward, Potter found a hole and bolted for the end zone to give SJSU a 28-14 lead. 
"Kenny does that," SJSU coach Ron Caragher said. "He's got that athletic ability. It keeps defenses honest when you've got an athletic quarterback who can make a multitude of plays." 
Said Ervin: "Kenny's magic. He does a good job creating something out of nothing." 
SJSU's rushing defense entered Saturday's game as the MWC's worst and gave up an early 79-yard touchdown to New Mexico's Teriyon Gipson. However, the Spartans surrendered just 208 yards on the ground, well below New Mexico's average of 254.6 per game. 
Cleveland Wallace III, who had a second-half interception, noted that the Spartans have one more win than they did last season. 
"We talk about climbing the mountain," the junior cornerback said. "This was a good first step." 
Austin Lopez became the first San Jose State place-kicker to reach 300 career points. He got No. 300 on his second PAT, which tied the game at 14-14 after fellow senior Hansell Wilson's 35-yard touchdown reception in the second quarter. 
Lopez now has 305 points, the last three coming on a 43-yard field goal in the fourth quarter. 
Junior linebacker Christian Tago and sophomore cornerback Maurice McKnight led SJSU's defense with 10 tackles apiece. Tago also blocked a field goal in the second quarter.
